body:
Vim supports compound filetypes (see [|'filetype'|](https://neovim.io/doc/user/options.html#'filetype')):

> When a dot appears in the value then this separates two filetype names.
> This works both for filetype plugins and for syntax files. More than one dot may appear.

nvim-lspconfig currently always compares the full 'filetype' option against the configured filetypes. So buffers set to multiple filetypes will not match at all.

Fix utility functions to match against each individual filetype

+---@param filetype string the filetype to check (can be a compound, dot-separated filetype; see |'filetype'|)
+---@param expected string|string[] the filetype(s) to match against
+---@return boolean
+function M.ft_matches(filetype, expected)

+---@return boolean
+function M.ft_matches(filetype, expected)

comment_data.body:
`vim.filetype.match` takes an existing buffer and returns the `filetype` (using the rules defined in `filetype.lua`). the result of that might be (for example) `c.doxygen`. see `|'filetype'|`:

```vimhelp
						*'filetype'* *'ft'*
'filetype' 'ft'		string	(default "")
			local to buffer  |local-noglobal|
...
	Setting this option to a different value is most useful in a modeline,
	for a file for which the file type is not automatically recognized.
	Example, for in an IDL file: >c
		/* vim: set filetype=idl : */
<	|FileType| |filetypes|
	When a dot appears in the value then this separates two filetype
	names.  Example: >c
		/* vim: set filetype=c.doxygen : */
<	This will use the "c" filetype first, then the "doxygen" filetype.
	This works both for filetype plugins and for syntax files.  More than
	one dot may appear.
	This option is not copied to another buffer, independent of the 's' or
	'S' flag in 'cpoptions'.
	Only normal file name characters can be used, `/\*?[|<>` are illegal.
```

In other words:

```lua
local ft = vim.filetype.match({buf=0})
ft == "c.doxygen"
util.ft_matches(ft, 'idl') == false
util.ft_matches(ft, 'c') == true
util.ft_matches(ft, 'doxygen') == true
```

 M.on_setup = nil
 
+---@param filetype string the filetype to check (can be a compound, dot-separated filetype; see |'filetype'|)
+---@param expected string|string[] the filetype(s) to match against
+---@return boolean
+function M.ft_matches(filetype, expected)

comment_data.body:
you can also pass filename  into match
```lua
        -- Using a filename without a buffer
        vim.filetype.match({ filename = 'main.lua' })

        -- Using file contents
        vim.filetype.match({ contents = {'#!/usr/bin/env bash'} })
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -21,6 +21,21 @@ M.default_config = {
 -- global on_setup hook
 M.on_setup = nil
 
+---@param filetype string the filetype to check (can be a compound, dot-separated filetype; see |'filetype'|)
+---@param expected string|string[] the filetype(s) to match against
+---@return boolean
+function M.ft_matches(filetype, expected)

comment_data.body:
yes, `vim.filetype.match` can take a filename and give us a filetype. but what we want is to take *that* filetype and check it against a list of filetypes (e.g. the ones supported by a particular lsp server). 

i.e. 

```lua
local ft = vim.filetype.match({ filename = 'main.lua' })
ft == "lua"
local filetypes_supported_by_current_client = { "lua", "sh", "c" }
util.ft_matches(ft, filetypes_supported_by_current_client) == true
```

Usually this would just be a `==` comparison but because a filetype can contain multiple filetypes (e.g. `c.doxygen`), we have to split it first.

```lua
local ft = vim.bo.filetype
ft == "yaml.ansible" -- this is not a filename! it is a _compound_ filetype
util.ft_matches(ft, "ansible") == true
util.ft_matches(ft, "yaml") == true
```

notice that `vim.filetype.match` doesn't help us do this comparison! it takes a buffer/file/filepath and gives us a filetype. but we don't need that. we **have** a filetype, it is provided by the caller. We are trying to match that against a list of acceptable filetypes, also provided by the caller.

+function M.ft_matches(filetype, expected)

+---@return boolean
+function M.ft_matches(filetype, expected)

comment_data.body:
A completely unique type is not desirable because we want to use the existing behaviors defined for the primary filetype. see [mfussenegger/nvim-ansible](https://github.com/mfussenegger/nvim-ansible/blob/cb5d0cc79c1864b72d5ae40a926a1176b18f1b65/ftdetect/ansible.lua#L23) or [pearofducks/ansible-vim](https://github.com/pearofducks/ansible-vim/blob/master/ftdetect/ansible.vim#L36). They both `set ft=yaml.ansible`.

You *want* ansible scripts to have the yaml filetype because that's what they are; we want (neo)vim to keep recognizing them as yaml files. if we set `ft=ansible` only, we lose the syntax highlighting/`match_words`/etc defined for yaml files. 

But the plugin additionally [sets various useful options](https://github.com/mfussenegger/nvim-ansible/tree/main?tab=readme-ov-file#usage) like `keywordprg`/`path`/`iskeyword`/`isfname` for `ansible` file types. Hence the reason for multiple file types.

The problem is that right now, nvim-lspconfig diverges from standard vim behavior because filetype matching operates on the entire `vim.bo.filetype` as a whole, rather than splitting it into individual file types. And every server has to be configured for every possible combination of multiple filetypes. see:

https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/blob/a3d9395455f2b2e3b50a0b0f37b8b4c23683f44a/lua/lspconfig/server_configurations/yamlls.lua#L4-L6

(notice that `yaml.ansible` is not included.

With this change, you can instead just specify `yaml`, and we'll match as long as *one* of your filetypes matches `yaml`

configs themselves can use vim.filetype.match() as shown in https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3145#discussion_r1782762191

comment_data.body: Been a while since I looked at this code, but I think that should work. I just didn't want to change the semantics of the existing code. e.g. your suggested check wouldn't match files with a manually set `filetype`; although I'm not sure if that is a negligible difference or not. Would lspconfig even spawn a server for e.g. `foobar.txt` where the user calls `:set filetype=elm`?

comment_data.body:
upon further thinking, I think `vim.filetype.match` will also fail when `filetype` is set via autocmd rather than `filetype.lua`. e.g. if we follow the suggestion from the sixtyfps server config:

https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/blob/aa615f62300465eef5115e0b7dfcf6dedc274f5d/lua/lspconfig/configs/sixtyfps.lua#L17-L23

opening `foo.60` will set `filetype` to `sixtyfps` but `vim.filetype.match({filename=fname})` will return `nil`

comment_data.body:
Even so, it's not acceptable to introduce another public API to lspconfig, we are trying to shrink it and upstream its API to Nvim core so that lspconfig is mostly "data-only".

I also strongly suspect that configs themselves don't need this new API.

comment_regular_data.body: rebase is ready, pending answers to questions raised in https://github.com/neovim/nvim-lspconfig/pull/3145#discussion_r1783179475

> I think `vim.filetype.match` will also fail when `filetype` is set via autocmd rather than `filetype.lu`

`vim.filetype.get_option()` is designed to handle that situation. 

So, to be clear:

- it looks like your internal changes to util.lua in this PR could make sense
- but configs themselves should find another way to meet this use-case (and if you can find an satisfactory answer to that, we can document it in lspconfig's help/CONTRIBUTING.md/etc).
    - please take a close look at the functions on `vim.filetype.*`
`lua/lspconfig/util.lua` is deprecated. This idea could make sense as an enhancement to Nvim core `vim.filetype` module, and/or `vim.lsp.config` or related features.

title: fix: support compound file-types
